segments.text: Today, this is an interview with Dr. Bill Gregory by Michael Picard on the 11th to the 30th at Texas A&M University concerning Vietnam.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge, I'm asking you to donate this tape to me at this time, Dr. Gregory.
Is that all right with you?
Yeah, you're welcome to use it in your classwork, but I want you to not use it in anything else.
All right.
Can I have a little information about your background and education?
I went to high school, a private school in Tennessee, Webb School.
Graduated there in 50, right at the start of the Korean War.
Then I spent two and a half years at SMU studying geology at that
At the time, the call to go flying airplanes was more than schoolwork, and so I dropped out of college, went into aviation cadets, and got my wings commissioned in 1955, February.
From that point on, I flew a multitude of airplanes, advanced jet gunnery,
school in 1958.
After that period of time, I flew some bombers, most notable of which was the B-58.
When we shut down the B-58s, I went over to Vietnam and flew gunships and was an operations officer there for a year.
And then concluded my career in the Air Force in 1973 and went back to college in
Started all over again and got degrees from Southwest Texas and Texas A&M.
Dr. Gregory, could you give me some ideas about your military education and what it consisted of?
Right, Mike.
Of course, it started off with the indoctrination forces down at Lackland.
basically everybody went through, we went through his aviation cadets, which is a little bit stricter program for six weeks.
And then for the next 12 weeks, it was 12 weeks long.
And then from that point, we went 12 months into flying school.
We had, of course, every morning or afternoon we flew.
And on the other part of the day, we had classroom activities.
So it was a pretty intensive 12 month program from that point on.
All the formal training that we had in the military was sort of a continuous activity of classroom or flight training.
I did squadron officer school, which is sort of prerequisite for anyone to continue in the Air Force.
All of my flying schools, like for B-47s, B-58s,
T-39s, F-100s, F-86s all took about three months each.
And so the career in the Air Force is a continuous education program.
You go from one school, one job.
As you advance in rank, you generally are re-schooled in certain other areas.
I also took a couple of ground courses
I was qualified as a surface and air transportation officer very early in my career and later chemical, biological and nuclear warfare officer.
In the last few years of my career, I attended riot control school in Fort Benning, Georgia, which was an unusual opportunity to mix with
mayors, law enforcement officials and whatever from Washington DC, Gary, Indiana, Kent State University and all over the country.
So our military education was a continuous thing.
I felt like I was in school for 20 years while I was in the service.
Dr. Gregory, why and when did you join the services?
Mike, I joined in
I applied in February of 1953 and had to go through a battery test.
Many of the youth of the United States wanted to get involved in the Korean War and there was of course a large draft going on.
A lot of people wanted to get in the Air Force or Navy rather than being in the ground forces in the Army.
I had to wait until October for a class assignment.
And during that time, I was almost drafted in the Army.
I came up and, fortunately, had a school deferment that allowed me to wait for my class assignment.
The motivation for it, I guess, from about the fourth grade, I've always wanted to fly airplanes.

utmost in my mind to to want to do something like that and of course the Korean conflict again put the romance of the war back in everybody's mind that you know had read about World War II or World War I and of course I was a young boy during World War II and had been a spotter for the
Civil Guard and all that sort of thing.
And just loved airplanes and had flown several times before that.
So my motivation was strictly to go fly airplanes and be a fighter pilot.
Dream of every young man that was very aggressive at that time.
Dr. Grege, were the man in your squadron mentally and physically trained from Vietnam?
And could you explain their training?
All right, Mike.
Certainly the individuals that were sent to Vietnam were considered to be professional soldiers.
The officers, of course, have been through extensive flying or navigation training and definitely were highly trained.
The mental aspects of the officers in my organization
I had very, very little problems with anybody other than to take care of the mission we were assigned.
They knew it was their job.
We had no doubt that we were there for that reason, and they did very well at it.
Our enlisted men, the NCOs, of course, had 10 to 15, 18 years of service and were
probably some of the best in their career fields.
Most of my NCOs were flight engineers.
It had four or five thousand flying hours in other aircraft and had taken care of aircraft and worked with them their entire career.
The younger people were

my gunnery people for the gunships we had and people we call illuminator operators who were it was a new field that was developing the gunnery the older gunnery people we always had people that handled munitions and what have you but very few operation individuals operated guns as they did in world war ii
until they developed the gunship.
And now again, we had people that were standing by these guns again.
They fired automatically, but they had to load them, maintain them, and even tear them down and rebuild them in flight while we were in a combat operation.
How successful was your gunship squadron during Vietnam?
Could you explain?
Mike, I'll try to.
I was the operations officer of a small
AC gunship called the AC-119G model.
It was the second generation of gunships in Vietnam.
The magic dragon was the first one, the AC-47.
We had another model of our airplane, the 119K, that had two jet engines and it had 20 caliber Gatling guns.
20 millimeter, excuse me.
We had the NATO round mini guns in four of them in the other, in our gunship and the K model also had four of those.
It was a fairly sophisticated airplane and had a radar system, a ballistic computer.
The K model also had a radar to
pick out targets with.

As far as sighting the thing, we had an automatic system that the navigator worked out of the backside of the airplane that we call a NOS, a night observation device, and it gave you a negative relief picture, and you could see down into the jungle at night very clearly with it.
Our operation at Thompson-Nood Air Base in Saigon was, we were the only combat operation on the base.
As far as what we call a combat operation, we were the only operating outfit on the base that fired an enemy and was fired back upon.
There was another outfit in C-47s that dropped leaflets all the time that we called BS bombers, but ours was the single combat outfit there.

uh as far as the effectiveness of our group uh our the control for the combat area was right there at tonson and i was friends with several people carl skillar who was the commander of the command post and they were the people that gave us our clearances to fire and he always was amused when certain pilots of mine got up in the air because he knew the results would

grow up markedly on the days that these individuals flew and the motivation of these guys to do the job and try to to assist the the people that were defending themselves against the vietcong highly motivated throughout their 12-month tour of duty i would say that our combat operations we received the

A couple of presidential citations and what have you, which was normal for most outfits, but our greatest achievement was the fact that we never lost a man or an airplane in the 12 months I was there.
We had two minor Purple Hearts or really battle scratches from shells coming in the airplane, but the individuals
We were never even taken off flying status for their injuries.
And we were real proud that we never lost an airplane.

We, of course, came very close and took some severe hits, but the quality of the pilots who followed the tactical doctrine that we created there at Thompson, as long as they followed it, they stood a chance of surviving.
And we did.
I had personally came there with nine.
officer crew members and we all went home on the same airplane together which was a gratifying thing and we felt like we did quite a bit of good.

We were working out of Vietnam in Cambodia in areas that were called Freedom Deal and places like that that were classified by the White House as things that we needed to defend and still have good friends from
from the people of Cambodia.
One of them lives in the general room that lives up in Dallas now.
It's really an interesting thing to go day by day and feel like you are keeping these people alive, so to speak.
How many of your men or career are enlisted in your squadron?
The squadron we had there was 234 flying personnel.

On each aircraft, we had an eight-man crew, four officers and four enlisted men consisting of pilot, co-pilot, a navigator, an observation device operator, two gunnery men, a flight engineer, and an illuminator operator for the rear.
We had ten crews and

basically three other officers in the squadron so we had approximately 43 people we supposedly we had a maintenance officer I only saw a maintenance officer there three months so that was one of my additional duties while I was there maintenance and ops officer and at one time the squadron commander was gone for three months and so I got all three of the jobs so it was sort of a consuming job you you work from seven in the morning to seven at night
doing your regular duties.
I flew 175 combat missions while I was there on top of my regular duties.
In fact, the first five months I didn't take a day off.
And that was sort of what was expected and what was seen out of all the crew members.
Our gunners, who were always short of them, they flew a schedule of six days on and one day off.
Was there a difference between a career man and an enlisted man?
They had to join because of the draft.
Was there a difference in their performance?
In any big operations, you always have a few problems with people.
We were really blessed by the fact that we had very little problems with drugs in our operations.
To my knowledge, and of course this is just a guess, we had one person involved in heroin and he came in and turned himself in
three days before he went back.
He was a radio communications maintenance person, enlisted man.
I always wondered about him.
He smiled all the time and seemed like he was happy and he was hooked on heroin.
That was when the time he turned himself in was about June of
of 1971 when they started the Golden Stream operations, which was checking people for drugs out of Vietnam and trying to start controlling some of the input back into the United States.
I'm sure there must have been some marijuana smoking there.
To my knowledge, I know of no pilot or officer crew member who was ever involved with any
Hallucinogenic drug now.
We all probably drank too much.
After missions and we had a what we call a party hooch.
And I was able to.
Get for our squadron just a month after I got there and.
We.
As officers 43 of us.
Consumed a tremendous amount of beer each month.
In fact, we flew 100 cases in from Philippines each month and that was not enough to get us through.

But after a four-hour mission in the night or in the daytime when your people are shooting at you, you probably need a beer or two or four or five to unwind before you hit the bed and think about getting up for the next mission.
As far as any other problem with these guys, I don't guess I've ever worked in a more professional outfit.
Our maintenance people
worked around the clock sometimes just to keep our airplanes going when we had a bad string of maintenance problems.
We just had minimum amount of maintenance failures and we ended up with a efficiency rating of 97% at the end of the 12 months, which is, I've forgotten what the person said when he told me about it,
We eclipsed any other American operation in Vietnam by a number of points.
I was really proud to work with guys like that that were so dedicated.
What were your daily operations during your squadron?
My normal operation was down at the office at 7 o'clock in the morning.

handle the scheduling scheduling problems the maintenance problems all the paperwork that develops in an operation like that being available when we had a pre-chef radio contact with all our aircraft all the way out to Phnom Penh and whenever they had a took a hit or or had a main engine problem or something that was going to give them some trouble we were able to

go through the emergency procedures and got them all back in a couple times we had to put them in the nom panel overnight and then send people out to repair the airplane and of course we could not and did not stay overnight in cambodia there was a decree by the ambassador there that no military people more than 18 people assigned would ever be in cambodia 24 hours so when we airplane go down we had to go in and work eight hours and come out
It added an extra load to our operation as anything like that does.
But otherwise, I guess majority, I'd say over half of my missions were nighttime missions.
After finishing at about 7 o'clock, I'd get some dinner and then either set one of the pilots down and tell him I was taking his mission or fly along as an evaluation.

I was also the senior instructor pilot for the operation, and I had to watch and see who was ready to become upgraded to instructor pilot status, how they were running their crews, and sometimes if one of my young line pilots was looking a little tired,
I'd just bump him and take his crew and let him get a nice rest extra and seem to help and keep him in good spirits.
What were some of the major problems of the combat flying operations in aircraft maintenance?
The maintenance problems?
Right.
Really the old C-119 was a forgiving old bird if you flew it by the manual.
One of the biggest problems I had was

had developed three different ways people would try to take the aircraft off after if they lost an engine after decision point and the book was the only accurate one you flew it on an exact acceleration curve climb speed and vertical velocity people had generated thought of pulling it off early which is always the kiss of death i think and the other people would
leave it on the ground and let it wind up high and then pull it up, but you ended up out of the flying envelope, so to speak, and the people before me lost two airplanes.
One of the things I demanded of my pilots, and I jumped up and down on the tables, danced, screamed, hollered, and cried, whatever to do to get them to listen to me and to operate the airplane
by the book.

As long as we were within legitimate gross weight limits and we were very careful about our figuring out our center of gravity and how much cargo we could carry depending on the temperature and what have you and we would carry that would limit or determine the amount of cans of ammunition we'd carry.
We'd carry up sometimes as high as 42 cans of ammunition which is a lot of
things to fire at the enemy.
And we would offload those as the temperature increased and what have you.
And I had a couple of young pilots who were still my friends that were able to bring the airplane around, never getting much above 200 or 300 feet, following what the book said.
Didn't have to dump their ammo cans out for the local Viet Cong to get hold of, but able to get back in.
In fact, one young man, Captain Thompson, the first time he did it, I thought he was going to crash.
I happened to be watching his takeoff and saw him lose the engine.
And I really chewed his tail up one side, down the other when he got it back into the parking lot.
More than one mission had gone by.
I think his second mission after that he lost an engine on takeoff.
And I also had one of the, I think the bias wing commander with him.
He made a perfect climb to altitude back in for a landing.
And he was just really impressed about how the airplane worked when you did it exactly right.

and that sort of convinced people to do what I asked them to do and not try to improvise and so because of that we never had any problems other than the few hits that we took that were pretty severe battle damage we had a couple airplanes that were down for a number of weeks because of the damage they took but we were always able to get them back in safely and without any injuries or death

um were supplies hard to come by and if so why well yes like at times uh finding the right parts for our for our engines were were very difficult uh propellers and engine nose cones and that sort of thing really are at the
At that time, that engine was also used in the KT-87 by the Strategic Air Command, so there was a high demand rate because they had a tremendous schedule of flying.
Of course, we had six units with aircraft, 10 aircraft each flying in Vietnam on a 24-hour-a-day basis, so you're really putting time on engines.
We were always improvising.
The Arvin people had C119s down at the other end of the field, and we did an awful lot of under-the-table trading with those guys.

It pretty well equalized out, but they were really good at helping us when we just came up to a critical point and we needed a carburetor or a magneto or something, and it wasn't available and it wasn't going to be in, and we just had to have the aircraft.
They really helped us out.
I guess the key word in a combat operation in a wartime situation is the best grounder is going to have the best outfit.
And we certainly had some of the best there were.
We became so mobile.
We had 17 vehicles when I left there.
And when I arrived, we had three.
And so I had run a motor pool one time.
There were things available there and how to get them and who to talk to.
We got the operation going.
It was quite a show.
Were there any cases of corruption in the squadron?
Could you explain?
Mike, I don't know of anything that you could classify as corruption.
We traded things back in the fourth.

and i wouldn't call that corruption at all the the no one ever stole anything if that's what you're saying now in vietnam there were stories about people getting very rich running officers clubs or nco clubs uh i'm sure selling supplies in the black market and what have you and i know i know that did exist and probably most of the people that had been there and left there sold their little
refrigerators on the black market when they left the country.
Probably a lot of them sold their cigarettes downtown to make a few bucks and I guess that's probably as corrupt as I would think that anything happened.
We did a lot of dealing with army groups and we had amazing times with the things that they gave to us in return.
They had a real problem because their young troops were not allowed to buy hard liquor until they were 21 years old.
And the average age of the Army line troops was probably about 19 years old.
And so they could only have beer.
And if you're out there getting shot at every day and looking at the guys through the jungle, I would think...

i don't know what psychologists have to say about it but you sure need some sort of tranquilizer and the only one that was readily available to everybody was drugs of any sort i mean pure heroin marijuana you know just hold your hand out somebody could put some in there but hard whiskey was hard to come by we all had ration cards and probably were allowed more booze than we needed and

About once a month, once every two months, we would collect everybody's ration card and go buy two or three cases of booze, whatever we could dig up with our extra tickets, and send them up to our buddies up at Benoit.
And sure enough, in a few days, a case of filet mignons would show up on the doorstep or something like that, and I guess that's corruption of sorts, but we thought maybe we were doing...

our bit and of course we were paying for our booze out of our pocket to see if we could help alleviate the situation up there and we would just take those steaks and we had a couple of barbecue pits out back of the operations building and we'd stand down for about two hours except for one airplane that was always in the air and we'd have us a big steak fry and have a big time and then we'd go back to the business we were there for
Okay, I see.
What was the social life like off the base?
Mike, it was a typical wartime situation.
The crowds there was amazing.
Prostitution, of course, always follows armies everywhere and always will.
In fact, our enlisted...
all lived in a contract hotel downtown.
It would be located right in the middle of the prostitution district, which we always tried to get it changed, but it was the best hotel we could get.
So the location just wasn't very good.
We had some problems with venereal disease.
We got to where we called it Gunner's disease for a while.
That was one reason why we put the gunners on a 6-1 tour of duty.
If we gave them more than one day off, we always seemed to have them over in the flight surgeon's office.
So when we stayed on 6-1, they never seemed to get there, which I'm not sure where the cause and effect is, but it sure worked.
Socially,
There wasn't a lot of mixing.
We turned our organization over to the Arvin 30 days after I left, and I got to know the new squadron commander and operations officer very well.
The squadron commander was Vice President Key's personal tennis coach and not a very impressive person, but the operations officer was a young captain who was really on the ball.

We went out together a couple of times in Saigon, and of course I had to pass to where I could go in civilian clothes any time I wanted to because I had to be able to check on my people down in the area, but it gave me the latitude to go out, look around the bars and see if our guys were doing anything that was distracting.
And you need to stop.
Let me finish what I was saying.
I'll lead right into what you want to talk about.
The operations officer was a nice young man.
He took me out a couple times and showed me parts of Saigon that I would never imagine existed.
The old French-influenced restaurants and places.
I've been to nice restaurants, but nothing like what I saw with him.
And a whole different establishment of the sort of upper-crust society.
We spent the entire time I was there, we were training the Arvin people to take over our organization, their crew members.
They were all qualified in the 119, all their first pilots were.
Their co-pilot had somewhere between 50 and 150 hours, which in our system would not even get you out of flying school.
The first time we allowed one to try to land the aircraft, it was an exciting experience.
Their other, you know, their first pilots, their aircraft commander pilots were pretty experienced young men.
They knew what they were doing in the aircraft.
Did the Arvin want to fight during this time?
Or did they just want to be with their family?
You're getting into a structure, a system that I observed and I have my viewpoints on.
I'm not sure how accurate they are.
While I was there, we had a six or eight of us run at a top floor, you know, call it a penthouse.
It wasn't much of a place, a little apartment on top of this building.
And it was a place I used three or four times.

And of course, every time I was down there to spend the night and sit there and look out and watch the war and have a drink by myself, someone would get in trouble and get battle damage and they'd have to come dig me out of Saigon and bring me back at three o'clock in the morning.
So after about third or fourth try at that, I quit doing it.
But I got to know the lady that owned this place.
And it seemed to me that

The majority of the Vietnamese that I met and talked with through her and the other people that lived in that building, they were a very closely knit group and their area or block or what have you district was the most important thing and the rest of the country be damned.
They didn't have the national unity
that we expect the whole world has.
And so we, at times, I guess, in our political structure and our foreign operations, try to dictate what we think everybody ought to feel.
And probably their upbringings and social orders and whatever don't even come close to matching what we expect of them.
But that was one of the interesting things.
I don't know.
The Vietnamese that we trained seemed credible.
A lot of attitude was hard for us to understand.
But of course, there's so much difference in attitude between Westerner and Easterner.
You have to be so delicate in how you talk to them.
And you can't embarrass an aircraft commander who makes a bad landing in front of his people.
I mean, he's lost face completely.
You can't criticize them when you critique their flights afterwards.
You had to be very careful about what you said as a group, and individually you could take them aside and say, now, these are the things you probably ought to work on.
But you couldn't come straight out like you would to an American serviceman and say, look, you screwed up on this.
Read the book.
Let's sit back and see if we can get this thing right.

because they they just didn't operate or think at all the way we did and though they may be as intelligent or more intelligent we are in in many ways our two civilizations are quite opposed in thoughts and how we perceive them um did your opinions of the vietnamese change over the time period you were there
from when you got there and then from when you left?
Mike, a lot of things changed in my mind.
I remember in 1967, I believe that was the time of melee, 67, 68, something like that, when I was flying B-58s and a friend of mine who had flown B-58s had been to Vietnam for a combat

tour in the line 105 had been there doing uh may line and i really don't remember the year of may lie what have you but i do remember being very opinionated about how terrible i thought that they'd go out and shoot women and children and this guy who i respect a great deal looked at me and said bill if you haven't been there you don't know what you're talking about
And after being there, I can understand the things that motivated those people to do the things that we call war atrocities.
I suppose the reason why we didn't get to have Nuremberg trials in World War II is because we were the winners.
If we had lost, we had as many war atrocities happening by our own military people.
In everyday life, the brutality of people can exhibit to each other.
I don't suppose down deep inside we're much different than the German soldiers were or what have you.
But those young kids and women would kill you just as soon as, if they were on drugs or were dedicated to the Viet Cong or whatever they believed in, they were going to throw a hand grenade at you.
shoot you down with a gun as quickly as anybody else.
My view of what was going on in the war and the area changed.
My feeling for Vietnamese people has never been any other than they're a country that deserved to be a country.
They're nice people.
I don't know any Vietnamese now from the war.
Most of my work was over in Cambodia, so I'm more familiar with those folks.
They had a tough life.
We were dictating Western ideas to them.
Obviously, their leaders were quite corrupt.
Vice President Key certainly was.
They were making millions and millions of dollars out of the war, and it certainly wasn't helping the people.
Did they want to fight?
I don't know.
They had somebody there to fight for them the whole time.
Why should they fight?
But that country, the history of that area, has been 3,000 years of continuous conflict.
There's never been a peaceful time.
Probably today in the last year has probably been one of the more peaceful eras of their existence.
There had been constant conflict in that area forever.
So fighting is part of their existence.
See, in your opinion, why did we lose the war?
Well, that's not my opinion anymore than anybody else's, but we didn't lose the war.
We weren't there to win it is our problem.
As any time when you have
And this is speaking as a military person.
And I don't believe in a lot of the things that I went there believing in back in 1970.
But the people that try to run the military machine as politicians, they don't understand what the operation has to be about.
And so you can't set a bunch of rules on yourself
and fight against somebody that has no rules and no boundaries.
We were limited.
We couldn't cross the DMZ.
We couldn't legally go out of Vietnam.
So they could go in and out.
They could regroup any place on the other side of the fence, and we were restricted from doing anything about it.
If we beat them, we couldn't take that territory.
Out in Cambodia, if we...
won that battle, we had to go back home again.
We couldn't stay in there and take it away from them.
And you can't win a war.
It's the same as we established in the Korean War.

If you limit yourself by a boundary and the other people have no boundaries that they have to be limited by, then they can have all their munitions and all their supplies there and just move in and out.
And so it's not the same kind of fire rules.
And there's a war of attrition.
So what was the answer?
The politicians say, okay, turn the Army and the Air Force loose and let them just take over the area.
Would that have started World War III with China?
Who knows?
But the mission we had there was one of containment, and you can't win that.
I mean, it's just, it's not possible.
So you get your people killed for trying to defend a piece of real estate, and they come in there and shoot at you and then go back home.
They're always fighting you and your vocation.
It's a heck of a way, and that's why there were so many hard feelings and why after 11 months I woke up one day and said, geez, nothing's changed.
11 months had gone by.
We shot a lot of ammunition.
We've killed a lot of the enemy.
We've done as good as we can, and nothing's changed.
We're still doing the same thing we were the first day I was here.
So we felt like we weren't ever gaining on them.
I see.
I'm going to ask you just one last question.
What impact did Vietnam have on your life during and after the war?
Mike, it's a hard question to ask.
During the war, it was something I trained for for 16 years.
I was a professional military person, a pilot.
I guess I flew 24 different aircraft in my career.
I had been to a number of combat schools.
I was finally putting to work something that I trained for for years.
It was a real, I guess you want to call it a macho man's world, a man's existence.
The men rule.
It was an interesting, interesting thing and an experience I would not like to repeat, but I darn sure wouldn't want to have missed it after the war or after my experience there.
I sort of put it in my hip pocket.
I guess I've talked about being in Vietnam 20 times since I've been there.
I don't talk about it very much.
Only when someone asks me to recount something about it.
But except when I get with my old buddies sometimes when we have reunions, then we might talk about it.
But just everyday conversation, I really don't have a lot to say.
It has not affected me.
one way or another.
I was awarded a DFC for killing a number of Viet Cong on a mission and getting the airplane back with some pretty good battle damage.
I kill people that it doesn't bother me.
It was a thing that they were trying to kill me and I was trying to keep these other people alive so I figured it was a
The thing we're all there for, as far as affecting my life, I don't think we've ever done that or ever will.
I felt I did it with honor and dignity, and if you do that, I think you can survive it.
I can't tell you what the people that were in the lines out in the jungle experienced, because that was a whole different world.
We went out on our missions, fought, came back, had a few beers, went to sleep on air conditioning,
BOQ with clean sheets.
How can you compare that with a guy that's living out in a foxhole someplace?
I'm sure he's got a completely different attitude on what it did for him then and in years to come.
And it's obvious in some of the things you see happening so many years later with people that were
in the trenches, so to speak, still having serious problems.
All right.
Thank you, Dr. Greger.
I appreciate your time.
